blurb: Visual studies explores culture through a wide variety of media. Visual studies is similar to art history, but focuses on how images affect us currently and how our culture affects the images we create.
notes: I think this is better encompassed by cinema studies and art history. It's kind of like a contemporary study of all visual things (images, films, art, video games) but its a bit too broad

blurb: Art history studies artistic design and development in historical contexts. Unlike other forms of art appreciation, art history is concerned with things like how and why an author creates a work of art based on his/her social environment.
mini_project: Watch at least five videos in this video series (not including the introductory video) and write about at least three common themes you found throughout them
summary: Art history is as much about discovering similarities between cultures as it is about differences. By examining the similarities between these historical analyses of art, you will begin to see how art history is conducted and how it can contribute to understanding art in historical contexts.
project: Choose a famous piece of art (you may use a website like http://totallyhistory.com/art-history/famous-paintings/ to get ideas) and conduct a research project on it. You may write about the artist, the artist's social and political environment, the reason for the work's creation, what previous works of art inspired the piece, how this piece has inspired future art, what people thought about the art at the time, how opinions about the piece have changed over time, etc. You may also include your opinion about the artwork.

blurb: Creative arts involves the actual creation of art. This includes drawing, painting, sculpting, and all forms of art creation.
mini_project: Watch all the "elements of art" videos in this playlist.
summary: Art is about exploration as well as expression. Although you may be comfortable creating art in specific ways, learning new tools will help you gain greater perspective on how to create impactful. Many of these techniques are presented in a basic form. You may independently look up some of these techniques in more advanced form.
project: Use some of the techniques you learned in the mini-project to create your own work of art.

blurb: Architecture is the practice of planning, designing, and building structures. It can be viewed as both an art and a science. Architecture incorporates creative design philosophies and also uses scientific principles to design stronger buildings or buildings that perform certain functions.
mini_project: Read through this lesson to get a better idea of the science behind bridge-building, which is one application of architectural skills.
summary: Bridges are among the most important structures built by architects. Not only do they serve an extremely functional purpose (transporting people and objects across gaps that would be otherwise impossible to pass), they must be built with the utmost safety in mind. A bridge that collapses could cause injuries for hundreds of people.
project: Build a popsicle bridge that can hold at least fifty pounds without breaking. The bridge you create should use structural design ideas that are used in bridges around the world!

blurb: Arabic is ancient language and one of the most widely spoken in the world. Many of its speakers reside in the Middle East as well as parts of North and East Africa. Given it is the liturgical language of Islam, Arabic reaches all corners of the world.
mini_project: Begin by learning the Arabic alphabet, which consists of 28 letters.
summary: Once you've learned the basics of the alphabet, you can then proceed to learn a bit more about subject pronouns, numbers, and grammar.

blurb: Chinese encompasses a large group of related dialects, the most widely-spoken of which is Mandarin. With over a billion speakers in China alone, Chinese dialects are among the most spoken languages in the world. Its importance in Western business is rising as the West increases its trade with China.
mini_project: Begin by learning Chinese characters and their significance.
summary: After learning about Chinese characters, you can also learn about tones and how they affect meaning.

blurb: Dutch is a West Germanic language, and is one of the most closely related languages to English. It is primarily spoken by people in the Netherlands.
mini_project: Although Dutch shares its alphabet with English, the pronunciation of its alphabet can be very different for certain letters. Learn and practice the differences with the following video.
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning Dutch through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: French is a Romance language and is the primary language of over two dozen countries, including several countries in Western and Central Africa. It is also a popular language for conducting business, especially in Europe.
mini_project: Counting numbers is an easy and fun way to begin your introduction to a language. Try learning how to count to 100 in French!
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning French through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: Greek is one of the oldest recorded languages in the world. It was widely used during classical antiquity, and maintains its importance in the study of Greek literature and theater.
mini_project: Start by learning the Greek alphabet in this mini-project.
summary: After learning the Greek alphabet, you can try to learn several essential Greek phrases

blurb: German is a major world language, with nearly 100 million native speakers and a similar amount who speak it as a foreign language. It is also highly related to English and Dutch.
mini_project: German is related to English, but you will soon learn that pronunciation can be very different between the two languages. Watch this video to help you practice your German pronunciation.
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning German through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: Hebrew is spoken in Israel and is the language of Jewish liturgy. It is also an important language for those who wish to study biblical texts.
mini_project: There are many reasons to study Hebrew. For this mini-project, write a brief explanation of what your reason is, and how you can guide your learning to best achieve your goals.
summary: Learn the Hebrew alphabet using the Project link. It is quite different from the English alphabet, so you may need to work hard to understand all of its nuances.

blurb: Hindi, the fourth most-spoken language in the world, is the official language of India but is also spoken by several emigrants and their descendants.
mini_project: Introduce yourself to the language by learning to introduce yourself and gaining an understand for fundamental grammar.
summary: After learning the basics of Hindi, try challenging yourself to learn more advanced concepts.

blurb: Italian is a Romance language, one of the closest to Latin. It is popular in several areas of Europe, with most speakers residing in Italy.
mini_project: Practice your Italian pronunciation with the following video.
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning Italian through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: Japanese is primarily spoken in Japan, but is widely studied throughout the world by non-Japanese students. For example, learning Japanese can foster a greater appreciation for Japanese popular culture (including video games, manga, and anime)
mini_project: Japanese doesn't have as many consonants as English, but it is important to be effective in your pronunciation. Watch this video to begin practicing your Japanese pronunciation.
summary: Develop your Japanese alphabet skills by learning both Hiragana and Katakana

blurb: This passion stems from one or two things: 1) an interest in a language that does not use the Roman alphabet or 2) East Asian cultures. Perhaps you watched Korean drama on Netflix or came across a Korean music video on YouTube. Or maybe the Korean characters (Hangul) seem easier to learn than Chinese characters (good news, it is easier to learn). Pursuing this passion will provide an introduction of Hangul, how to read it, and how to pronounce the characters. You won’t understand Korean after this mini-project, but you will have the tools you need to dive deeper into the language. You’re well on your way, you polyglot!
mini_project: Write about why you are interested in learning Korean. You may have been inspired by friends and family, or by music or film/television. Whatever the case, knowing why you are interested in the language will help motivate you through the difficult task of actually learning it!
summary: Complete all 6 lessons  on this website. After this introduction to Korean you should be able to recognize and draw a few basic characters and understand a bit more about the origins of the Korean language

blurb: Although Latin is not actively spoken by present-day populations, its influence on current languages cannot be understated. Romance languages, such as French, Spanish, Italian, and Portuguese, are descendants of Latin. And because of the influence of Romance languages on the English language, several English words and phrases have Latin roots. In addition to being able to read Latin texts, learning Latin will allow you to have a better understanding and appreciation for contemporary languages.
mini_project: Given that Latin is not generally spoken today, why are you interested in studying it? As mentioned in the introductory paragraph, Latin can be very helpful for understanding language today. It can also help in learning concepts in law, medicine, and science. Write about what Latin can offer to you. Feel free to use a search engine to discover new applications of the language.
summary: Although Latin's alphabet is similar to English's, there are subtle, but important differences. Practice the alphabet and the pronunciation using this video.

blurb: Also known as Farsi, Persian is the official language of Iran, Afghanistan, and Tajikistan, and is spoken sporadically in other countries. It has influenced Arabic, and remains an extremely important language for those interested in international relations with the Middle East.
mini_project: Try learning a few Farsi phrases using the following website. Choose at least 5 of the beginner phrases to practice and learn.
summary: Persian has a much different alphabet than English. Try learning the Persian alphabet, as well as some Persian numbers.

blurb: Portuguese is a Romance language spoken in Portugal, Brazil, multiple countries in the Southern Africa. Accordingly, it has a large presence in South America and bears linguistic resemblance to French, Italian, and especially Spanish.
mini_project: Practice your Brazilian Portuguese pronunciation with the following video.
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning Portuguese through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: Russian is spoken in Russia and neighboring countries, particularly those that were previously part of the Sovient Union. As one of the six official languages of the United Nations, Russian holds an important place in international relations.
mini_project: Try learning the Russian alphabet!
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning Russian through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: Swedish is a North Germanic language that is highly related to Norwegian and Danish. It is mainly spoken in Sweden, but people who speak Swedish can often understand Norwegian and Danish, making it a versatile language to know.
mini_project: Learn how to introduce yourself in Swedish!
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning Swedish through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: With hundreds of millions of native speakers, Spanish is one of the most widely spoken languages in the world. It is by far the second most common language in the United States, making it very useful for Americans to learn, especially those in the Southwest.
mini_project: You can practice your Spanish pronunciation using the following video.
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning Spanish through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: Turkish uses a form of the Latin alphabet, but has several distinctions from a language like English, such as subject-verb syntax and the importance placed on honorifics. It is spoken by several million people primarily concentrated in Eastern Europe and Western Asia.
mini_project: Learn how sounds in the Turkish language differ from sounds in English.
summary: If you are over 13 and have an email address, you can begin learning Turkish through Duolingo.com. Try completing at least five practice modules on the website.

blurb: Yiddish is considered a Germanic language, but it incorporates words from Hebrew and several other languages. It is the historical language of Ashkenazi Jews and continues to be practiced sporadically throughout the Jewish world.
mini_project: Yiddish is not a widely practiced language. Write a short description of why you are interested in learning Yiddish. You may use the mini-project link to help develop your ideas.
summary: Practice Yiddish using the following link. You can learn some elementary words and numbers. Once you feel comfortable, you may begin learning about grammar. At any stage of learning Yiddish, you should check out the Yiddish proverbs!

blurb: American Sign Language (ASL) is a popular second language that is predominantly used to allow people to communicate with and within deaf communities in North America, West Africa, and Southeast Asia
mini_project: After watching the introductory video, try memorizing the ASL alphabet and learn how to spell your name using it.
summary: Once you've mastered the alphabet, try learning 100 basic signs to get started in ASL.

blurb: Cinema Studies (also known as film studies) explores the relationship between movies and their social, political, and economic contexts. It also examines how movie-making allows unique forms of storytelling.
mini_project: Read through this article on basic film techniques. You may have recognized many of these techniques in the films you have watched. Think about how they're using in the media you've seen and how that correlates with the effect stated in the article.
summary: Most of the time, we watch movies simply to enjoy them. However, if we begin to consider the film in all of its contexts, we may end up appreciating it much more. By researching a movie that you already like very much, you can find how enjoying movies and studying them are very different, but are both enjoyable.
project: Think about your favorite movie. Search the internet for contextual information (information that tells more about how the movie fits into a particular time and place) such as where it was made, when it was made, who directed it, who wrote it, and if there are any deeper meanings within the plot. Watch the movie again while taking notes about how all the things you researched appear in the movie itself. A general website like wikipedia.org may be a good place to begin your research.

blurb: Sometimes called World or Global Literature, Comparative Literature is the study of international cultural expression. Despite the name, comparative literature can also examine the relationship between literature and other forms of media such as film, or other academic discipliens such as history or philosophy.
mini_project: Find up to three examples of books you have read that were not originally written in your spoken language. If you can't find three, you may also use books that have been written in your language, but in another country. You can use a website like goodreads to get started. Think about how these novels have been different from novels written in your country. This can include the style of writing, the organization of the plot, or the social, political, economic, or philosophical landscape in the story.
summary: The mini-project will get you thinking about comparative literature in a context relevant to your life. Now, you may use the project to show how comparative literature can be used to analyze international culture.
project: Choose one of the books you identified in the mini-project and write a short essay (two pages or less) on why the text deserves to be read in a comparative literature course. You can use any of the topics discussed in the mini-project to explain the book's cultural significance.

blurb: English studies includes the study of English literature and well as English linguistics
mini_project: A close reading is an extensive analysis of a passage of prose or poetry. Your mini-project will be to learn more about the process of close reading in order to prepare yourself to perform one. You may use the provided link to get started.
summary: Once you understand how a close reading should be down, try performing one with a passage from one of your favorite books. Alternatively, you can use the link provided to browse through close reading lesson plans at your level of education.

blurb: According to the American Folklore Society, "[f]olklore is the traditional art, literature, knowledge, and practice that is disseminated largely through oral communication and behavioral example." Those who study folklore are interested in the idea of societal expression and tradition, in formal or informal interactions.
mini_project: Describe a folk group and one or more of its customs.  What genres of folklore appear in this group’s repertoire?  Who are the people who perform this folklore?  What are the occasions for folklore performance?  Interpret the meaning or meanings of the tradition to the people who maintain it.
summary: Folklore is often misappropriately thought to only apply to past cultures. You may use the mini-project or the project to analyze more contemporary examples of folklore.
project: Collect a story (folktale, legend, joke, anecdote, personal experience narrative) or a folk poem.  Transcribe the text, as close as possible to the words you heard (if possible, work with a tape recorder).  Describe the context (who performed it, to whom, where, when, why).  Have you heard variants?

blurb: Music theory studies how concepts of music translate to how music is created. This includes learning how factors like meter, rhythm, and time signatures contribute to the production of music.
mini_project: Complete the video series on the basics of music.
summary: This video series is designed for someone who is just being introduced to music. It covers the basics of how music is understood and how it is created.
notes: (I wasn't able to find a good, short video about music theory that would be accessible to students. The mini-project is pretty introductory though)

blurb: Those who study theater are interested in how theatrical performances relate to their social and historical contexts.
mini_project: Try reading some critiques of theatrical plays. This will help you understand what experts are interested in when analyzing theater. The link contains a couple basic examples of theater critiques, as well as tips of writing reviews. You are encouraged to find more. Publications such as the New York Times and the Chicago Tribune regularly publish theater reviews.
summary: Now that you've read a critique of theater, you can try writing one! You can use either a written play that you've read, or a dramatic performance you've watched. You may use the Project link for tips on how to get started.

blurb: Biological Engineering or bioengineering (including biological systems engineering) is the application of concepts and methods of biology (and secondarily of physics, chemistry, mathematics, and computer science) to solve real-world problems related to the life sciences or the application thereof, using engineering's own analytical and synthetic methodologies and also its traditional sensitivity to the cost and practicality of the solution(s) arrived at.
mini_project: Design a Device to Separate Mixtures
summary: Here, Cadets will learn the mechanisms by which antifungal medications work, and compare the effectiveness of different ones
Learn about how muscles work and get tired through an EMG-based lab

blurb: Chemical engineering is a branch of engineering that applies physical sciences (e.g. chemistry and physics) and life sciences (e.g. biology, microbiology and biochemistry) together with mathematics and economics to produce, transform, transport, and properly use chemicals, materials and energy. Biomolecular engineering is the application of engineering principles and practices to the purposeful manipulation of molecules of biological origin. Biomolecular engineers integrate knowledge of biological processes with the core knowledge of chemical engineering in order to focus on molecular level solutions to issues and problems in the life sciences related to the environment, agriculture, energy, industry, food production, biotechnology and medicine.
mini_project: Design Your Own Silly Putty
summary: Through the project, students should learn about energy conversion, solar cells, and renewable energy

blurb: Computer science is the scientific and practical approach to computation and its applications. It is the systematic study of the feasibility, structure, expression, and mechanization of the methodical procedures (or algorithms) that underlie the acquisition, representation, processing, storage, communication of, and access to information, whether such information is encoded as bits in a computer memory or transcribed in genes and protein structures in a biological cell.
mini_project: Teach a Computer to Draw Shapes
summary: Cadets will learn to create their own animations using nothing but a plain-text editor and a Web browser

blurb: Electrical engineering is a field of engineering that generally deals with the study and application of electricity, electronics, and electromagnetism. Electrical engineering has now subdivided into a wide range of subfields including electronics, digital computers, power engineering, telecommunications, control systems, radio-frequency engineering, signal processing, instrumentation, and microelectronics.
mini_project: Cadets will learn how digital data is stored and use magnets to store their own data
summary: Cadets will build their own (AM) crystal radio, learning about radio transmission and EM signals in the process.

blurb: Systems engineering is an interdisciplinary field of engineering that focuses on how to design and manage complex engineering systems over their life cycles.
Integrated Priduct Design merge the disciplines of design, engineering and business for the purpose of creating compelling new products and experiences.
mini_project: Slip Rings Redesign

blurb: Mechanical engineering is the discipline that applies the principles of engineering, physics, and materials science for the design, analysis, manufacturing, and maintenance of mechanical systems. It is the branch of engineering that involves the design, production, and operation of machinery. It is one of the oldest and broadest of the engineering disciplines.
mini_project: DIY Air Conditioner

blurb: Materials science, also commonly known as materials science and engineering, is an interdisciplinary field which deals with the discovery and design of new materials.

As the name indicates, biochemistry is a hybrid science: Biology is the science of living organisms and chemistry is the science of atoms and molecules, so biochemistry is the science of the atoms and molecules in living organisms. Its domain encompasses all the living world with the unifying interest in the chemical structures and reactions that occur in living systems.
mini_project: CO2 and Photosynthesis

blurb: Biology is a natural science concerned with the study of life and living organisms, including their structure, function, growth, evolution, distribution, and taxonomy.
mini_project: Dehydrated Potato

blurb: Biophysics is an interdisciplinary science using methods of, and theories from, physics to study biological systems. Biophysics spans all scales of biological organization, from the molecular scale to whole organisms and ecosystems. Biophysical research shares significant overlap with biochemistry, nanotechnology, bioengineering, computational biology and (complex) systems biology. It has been suggested as a bridge between biology and physics.

Epidemiology is the science that studies the patterns, causes, and effects of health and disease conditions in defined populations. It is the cornerstone of public health, and informs policy decisions and evidence-based practice by identifying risk factors for disease and targets for preventive healthcare.

Immunology is a branch of biomedical science that covers the study of all aspects of the immune system in all organisms.[1] It deals with the physiological functioning of the immune system in states of both health and diseases; malfunctions of the immune system in immunological disorders (autoimmune diseases, hypersensitivities, immune deficiency, transplant rejection); the physical, chemical and physiological characteristics of the components of the immune system in vitro, in situ and in vivo.
mini_project: Oral Bacteria

blurb: Neurology (from Greek: νεῦρον, neuron, and the suffix -λογία -logia "study of") is a branch of medicine dealing with disorders of the nervous system. Neurology deals with the diagnosis and treatment of all categories of conditions and disease involving the central and peripheral nervous system (and its subdivisions, the autonomic nervous system and the somatic nervous system); including their coverings, blood vessels, and all effector tissue, such as muscle.[1] Neurological practice relies heavily on the field of neuroscience, which is the scientific study of the nervous system.
mini_project: Blind Spot in Vision

blurb: Nursing is a profession within the health care sector focused on the care of individuals, families, and communities so they may attain, maintain, or recover optimal health and quality of life.
mini_project: Corrosiveness of Soda

blurb: Pharmacology (from Greek φάρμακον, pharmakon, "poison" in classic Greek; "drug" in modern Greek; and -λογία, -logia "study of", "knowledge of") is the branch of medicine and biology concerned with the study of drug action,[1] where a drug can be broadly defined as any man-made, natural, or endogenous (within the body) molecule which exerts a biochemical and/or physiological effect on the cell, tissue, organ, or organism (sometimes the word pharmacon is used as a term to encompass these endogenous and exogenous bioactive species).
mini_project: Rubber Bones

blurb: Psychology is the study of mind and behavior.[1][2] It is an academic discipline and an applied science which seeks to understand individuals and groups by establishing general principles and researching specific cases.
mini_project: Learning and Color Experiment

blurb: Computational logic is the use of logic to perform or reason about computation. It bears a similar relationship to computer science and engineering as mathematical logic bears to mathematics and as philosophical logic bears to philosophy.
mini_project: Checking vs. Savings

blurb: Mathematics (from Greek μάθημα máthēma, “knowledge, study, learning”) is the study of topics such as quantity (numbers), structure, space, and change. There is a range of views among mathematicians and philosophers as to the exact scope and definition of mathematics.
mini_project: Mean, Median and Range

blurb: Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary scientific study of the mind and its processes. It examines what cognition is, what it does and how it works.
Anatomy is the branch of biology concerned with the study of the structure of organisms and their parts;[1] it is mainly divided into zootomy and phytotomy.
mini_project: Learn  Skeletal System

blurb: Astronomy is a natural science which is the study of celestial objects (such as stars, galaxies, planets, moons, asteroids, comets and nebulae), the physics, chemistry, and evolution of such objects, and phenomena that originate outside the atmosphere of Earth, including supernovae explosions, gamma ray bursts, and cosmic microwave background radiation.
mini_project: Learn Earth Movement

blurb: Chemistry is a branch of physical science that studies the composition, structure, properties and change of matter.
mini_project: Accelerate Rusting

blurb: Environmental science is a multidisciplinary academic field that integrates physical, biological and information sciences (including but not limited to ecology, biology, physics, chemistry, zoology, mineralogy, oceanology, limnology, soil science, geology, atmospheric science, geography and geodesy) to the study of the environment, and the solution of environmental problems.
mini_project: Carbon in the Atmosphere

blurb: Geology (from the Greek γῆ, gē, i.e. "earth" and -λoγία, -logia, i.e. "study of, discourse"[1][2]) is an earth science comprising the study of solid Earth, the rocks of which it is composed, and the processes by which they change.
mini_project: Homemade Volcano

blurb: Physics (from Ancient Greek: φυσική (ἐπιστήμη) phusikḗ (epistḗmē) "knowledge of nature", from φύσις phúsis "nature"[1][2][3]) is the natural science that involves the study of matter[4] and its motion through space and time, along with related concepts such as energy and force.
mini_project: Create Lightening

blurb: Bioethics is the study of the typically controversial ethical issues emerging from new situations and possibilities brought about by advances in biology and medicine. It is also moral discernment as it relates to medical policy, practice, and research. (Wiki)
mini_project: For understanding bioethics it is best to to think through different situations that might arise. Choose 3 case studies from the list provided and discuss the cases with your family, friends, or others who might hold a differign view point from your own to see all of the points of view that arise.
summary: The case studies draw on several controversial topics with few clear resolutions. After going through the mini-project you should be able to see the range of opinions that arise during these hotly debated topics and gotten a feel for how important these discussions are.

blurb: This passion stems from a desire to weave together the tapestry of your environment so that everyone's needs are taken into consideration and the beauty of the local culture is able to shine through. Looking at all of the different needs of the residents of an area, working with restricted budgets, and thinking through different area layouts to build work, play, and living spaces for people is what City and Regional Planners work to do.
mini_project: You have been assigned to imagine, detail, and construct the layout for a new city, Tomorrowton. Write down the demographics, type of work in the city, location, natural environment, and all other details you can think of for your city. Next you will need create a snapshot of your city using the link provided. Make sure to consider all of the needs of the different people who will be living and visiting your city throughout the year. [A more advanced version of this project can be performed by assigning costs to each of the different items that can be used for construction, forming groups for this project, and giving different budgets for designing Tomorrowton.] Once you have finished creating your city, discuss your snapshot with other participants in the project as well as your friends and family.
summary: City planning is all about figuring out the needs of the group you are designing for, the feel of the environment that best reflects the culture of the people, and working with the local people to make the future they want to see.

blurb: Criminology is the scientific study of the nature, extent, management, causes, control, consequences, and prevention of criminal behavior, both on the individual and social levels. (Wiki)
mini_project: To explore this passion you will be working to solve a crime or series of crimes. As a detective you will have to think through how the crime could have played out, who could have done the crime, their motives, as well as the reasons why someone would have commiteed the crime.
summary: This project should have shown the approach needed for taking apart a crime scene, understanding all of the different players involved, finding and following leads, as well as the mechanics at play when working through a case.

blurb: A passion for education means you love to watch people learn and helping them along the way gives you joy.

passion: Art and Archaeology of the Mediterranean World

blurb: Asian American Studies is an academic discipline which critically examines the history, experiences, culture, and policies relevant to Asian Americans. It is closely related to other Ethnic Studies disciplines, such as African American Studies, Middle Eastern studies (including Jewish studies and Arab studies), Latino/a Studies, and Native American Studies.

Communication (from Latin commūnicāre, meaning "to share") is a purposeful activity of exchanging information and meaning across space and time using various technical or natural means, whichever is available or preferred. On a fundamental level, communication entails three steps 1) thought by the sender, 2) encoding of thoughts by the sender in words or other methods, and 3) decoding of the message by the receiver. (Wiki)

Demography is the statistical study of populations, including of human beings. As a very general science, it can analyze any kind of dynamic living population, i.e., one that changes over time or space (see population dynamics).

Gender studies is a field for interdisciplinary study devoted to gender identity and gendered representation as central categories of analysis. This field includes women's studies (concerning women, feminism, gender, and politics), men's studies and LGBT studies.

Jewish studies (or Judaic studies) is an academic discipline centered on the study of Jews and Judaism. Jewish studies is interdisciplinary and combines aspects of history (especially Jewish history), Middle Eastern studies, Asian studies, Oriental studies, religious studies, archeology, sociology, languages (Jewish languages), political science, area studies, women's studies, and ethnic studies. Jewish studies as a distinct field is mainly present at colleges and universities in North America.

Latin American studies critically examines the history, culture, politics, and experiences of Latin Americans in Latin America and often also elsewhere (such as Latinos/Hispanics in the United States).
Latina/o studies is an academic discipline which studies the experience of people of Hispanic ancestry in the United States. Closely related to other ethnic studies disciplines such as African American studies, Asian American studies, and Native American studies, Latino studies critically examines the history, culture, politics, issues, and experiences of Hispanic people.

Sociology is the scientific study of social behavior or society, including its origins, development, organization, networks, and institutions. It is a social science that uses various methods of empirical investigation and critical analysis to develop a body of knowledge about social order, social disorder and social change.

Science, technology and society (STS), also referred to as science and technology studies is a branch or offspring of science studies. It considers how social, political, and cultural values affect scientific research and technological innovation, and how these, in turn, affect society, politics and culture.

Telecommunication occurs when the exchange of information between two or more entities (communication) includes the use of technology. Communication technology uses channels to transmit information (as electrical signals), either over a physical medium (such as signal cables), or in the form of electromagnetic waves. The word is often used in its plural form, telecommunications, because it involves many different technologies.

Urban studies is the diverse range of disciplines and approaches to the study of all aspects of cities, their suburbs, and other urban areas. This includes among others: urban economics, urban planning, urban ecology, urban transportation systems, urban politics, sociology and urban social relations. This can be contrasted with the study of rural areas and rural lifestyles.

Accounting, or accountancy, is the measurement, processing and communication of financial information about economic entities. Accounting, which has been called the "language of business", measures the results of an organization's economic activities and conveys this information to a variety of users including investors, creditors, management, and regulators. (Wiki)
mini_project: The best way to know what accounting and business is like is to get your mind around some of the basics. Work through the following guide ( http://www.accountingcoach.com/accounting-basics/explanation ) either on your own, with a friend/family member, or in a group to think through the basics of accounting. Then take the quiz on your own to see how much you remember.
summary: Accounting is how businesses let people know how they are doing. After completing the mini-project you should have a better grasp of the kinds of things those passionate about speaking "the language of business" do every day.

blurb: The study of how people in a large company or organization behave and react to each other, and of how the organization can be made to work more effectively ( http://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/business-english/organizational-dynamics )

Economics is the social science that studies economic activity to gain an understanding of the processes that govern the production, distribution and consumption of goods and services in an economy. (Wiki) The intro video gives a broad overview of some key terms important for being passionate about economics.

Finance is a field that deals with the allocation of assets and liabilities over time under conditions of certainty and uncertainty. Finance also applies and uses the theories of economics at some level. Finance can also be defined as the science of money management. (Wiki)
mini_project: To learn more by doing you will practice the basics of finance. Work through the problems in the Time Value of Money: Basic section, search any terms that are confusing to you, and check to make sure you understand any mistakes you made.
summary: After this project you should be able to understand a few key concepts of finance as well as how to apply them. You can dive deeper into your passion and get on your way to finding out more about your potential passion for making companies sustainable regardless of their economic climates.

blurb: International Relations is the study of relationships among countries, the roles of sovereign states, inter-governmental organizations (IGO), international non-governmental organizations (INGO), non-governmental organizations (NGO), and multinational corporations (MNC). (Wiki) International relations in business works to think through how businesses in different countries work together in the global marketplace. The intro video talks about some of the factors at play when we thinking about international relations.
mini_project: You are going to dive deeper into this passion by going past the first 10 videos in the playlist following the introduction video. Think through the topics covered and see how they can be related to current news you have heard in your own life.
summary: This passion is all about think through how people and organizations from different cultures come together. After completing this mini-project you should have a better understanding of the key terms, the consequences of the decisions being made, and the scale on which some of these decisions operate and need to be analyzed.

blurb: This is exactly as it sounds, Legal Studies is the study of law.
mini_project: It is hard to know the law without examples to work through. For this project you will work through questions to see what your reasoning should be and ways that you could better think through questions. Form question sets of 5 or 10 using the linked tool and work to get more than 80% of the questions right. If the questions are difficult form teams and think through the problems together. Make sure to be share your reasoning and make logical yet creative jumps in forming your arguments.

blurb: Business ethics (also corporate ethics) is a form of applied ethics or professional ethics that examines ethical principles and moral or ethical problems that arise in a business environment. It applies to all aspects ofbusiness conduct and is relevant to the conduct of individuals and entire organizations. (Wiki)
mini_project: Business ethics involves a variety of situations. In this mini-project, you will read about situations that arise in business and write about how you think the situation should be ethically handled.
summary: Each year, the Ethisphere Institute names an international list of companies it deems to be the most ethical. Choose a company from this list and research some of their ethical business practices. Write about these practices, and also write about practices that would be deemed non-ethical. Form an opinion about whether you believe the company deserves its position about on the list, using your research as evidence.

blurb: Management in businesses and organizations is the function that coordinates the efforts of people to accomplish goals and objectives by using available resources efficiently and effectively. (wiki)
mini_project: We perform management skills in all parts of our lives. For this mini-project you will exercise your skills in time management. Pretend you are an adult with a spouse and two children. Your job pays decently when you work 40 hours for 5 days a week, but you have the option of working more hours and more days. Plan out a typical week in your life, being sure to include time for work, eating, leisure/hobbies, family, and sleep. You can do this on paper, or use your favorite online/eletronic calendar.
summary: Sometimes the best way to practice management skills is to assess a hypothetical (or real) problem and develop a solution. This is know as a case study. You will try to analyze this case, giving your opinion on how it should be managed.
project: Amy, a registered dietitian recently promoted to director of Food and Nutrition, is trying to make the kitchen schedule for next month. All day long, employees drop into her office to let her know their needs and desires. A few employees can work only 3 or 4 days in a row, because they get too tired otherwise. Most every employee has a shift preference. Some of the employees already are asking to change their regular weekend off. Some of the employees are requesting specific days of the week off. A couple of employees have stated that they have child care issues, and that if they are scheduled on certain shifts or days, they will need to leave in the middle of the day to get their children off the school bus or to find them a place to stay after school. After several hours of working on the schedule, Amy thinks that she is finished, and she makes copies to distribute to all of the employees and then hangs another copy on the bulletin board in the kitchen. When she comes back later, she finds that employees have written all over the schedule—switching shifts and days with each other, circling days that they do not think they can work, and writing notes on the bottom of the schedule to each other. She also finds a number of day-off requests in her mailbox and under her office door for days that the employees were already scheduled to work. Worse yet, the employees are very disgruntled and come to her saying things such as, “I told you that I cannot work on Tuesdays. Did you forget?” Amy has no memory of several of these conversations. What should Amy do to fix these issues?

blurb: Marketing includes all the ways a company communicates with others. This can include how its corporate image, public relations, and its product's brand.
Operations and Information Management is about achieving the most efficient result using the resources at hand, which can include employees, wealth, or capital
